title: Full vs Incremental Data Loads Explained
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.confessionsofadataguy.com%2Ffull-vs-incremental-data-loads-explained%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019970e3d754-1f14bda1-e012-403a-bce4-3faf7f0b0e16-000000/AAS1LfGeg_Mj3F-xS9rhbKMG0UxYHf2DMY2IwVR2UkM=423
summary: Full vs Incremental Data Loads Explained (9 minute video) Full data loads excel in simplicity and reliability for small datasets or high-integrity needs, but become inefficient for large-scale systems due to high resource use. Incremental loads offer efficiency and scalability for bigger data volumes, though they demand strong change-tracking to prevent errors, with hybrid methods often blending both for optimal balance based on size, frequency, resources, and integrity requirements.

summary: A Gentle Introduction to vLLM for Serving (6 minute read) vLLM is an open-source engine for serving large language models that boosts throughput, lowers latency, and reduces memory waste. It does this via innovations like PagedAttention, which virtualizes key/value cache memory into pages and dynamically reuses them, especially helpful for handling long input sequences and many users at once.

title: What's the limit of what can be in a TXT record?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdgl.cx%2F2025%2F09%2Fimages-over-dns%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019971152b00-8e70489c-7c33-4396-8a19-d1fd43eb37a5-000000/6LrZyc2eba7sfVCeQ3wdmVvz4Ypu1ccKV4nzDfEHxO8=423
summary: What's the limit of what can be in a TXT record? (3 minute read) TXT records contain multiple character-strings that are limited in length. The size of a TXT record is limited by the size of the DNS payload, which for TCP is up to 64KB. This could have security implications as it allows attackers to tunnel large payloads to browsers.

title: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fobsidian.md%2Fblog%2Fless-is-safer%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/01000199711a1e53-07c06204-a37c-40aa-bb2d-ea8e63c2117d-000000/5XLrgSuTI1jEpSpTXECSlYyh6W9mal3Io5kwtGVAYAw=423
summary: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks (3 minute read) Obsidian reduces supply chain attack risks by minimizing third-party dependencies, re-implementing or forking code where possible, and shipping only a small, controlled set of version-pinned libraries. It further protects users through slow, review-heavy dependency updates, strict lockfiles, no postinstall scripts, and deliberate release delays that allow time for the ecosystem to flag malicious versions.

summary: Lazyssh (GitHub Repo) Lazyssh, a terminal-based, interactive SSH manager written in Go, allows users to manage servers and navigate, connect, and transfer files from their terminal using their existing `~/.ssh/config` file. The tool, inspired by lazydocker and k9s, uses the system's native SSH binary and does not store or modify credentials.

summary: Extending deployment pipelines with Amazon ECS blue green deployments and lifecycle hooks (5 minute read) Amazon ECS now supports native blue/green deployments along with lifecycle hooks, enabling custom logic such as governance checks, automated tests, and manual approvals directly in deployment pipelines. title: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fobsidian.md%2Fblog%2Fless-is-safer%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199712f9275-e0609338-0204-4d9f-9595-4fedb2997d27-000000/cCDG2ScbnqYXA1Ql_6F-E_8QLoAsfPHpxGq2g6TG49Q=423
summary: Less is safer: how Obsidian reduces the risk of supply chain attacks (3 minute read) Supply chain attacks involve malicious updates sneaking into open-source code. Obsidian minimizes risk by depending on minimal third-party code, often re-implementing functions or forking modules when feasible. When using larger libraries, Obsidian uses version pinning and lockfiles, guaranteeing a deterministic build process.

title: Bringing Observability to Claude Code: OpenTelemetry in Action
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 16 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsignoz.io%2Fblog%2Fclaude-code-monitoring-with-opentelemetry%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199712f9275-e0609338-0204-4d9f-9595-4fedb2997d27-000000/svtnuH_ahyQKsDvOdWNKcq43O9WOMk3cM4ur4TnUF3Y=423
summary: Bringing Observability to Claude Code: OpenTelemetry in Action (16 minute read) Claude Code can be monitored using OpenTelemetry and SigNoz to gain visibility into its usage and impact. By using OpenTelemetry for data collection and SigNoz for visualization and alerting, teams can track important metrics like token usage, cost, and performance trends. This article shows how to set up OpenTelemetry instrumentation for Claude Code.

title: Claude Can Prove It
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 19 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.galois.com%2Farticles%2Fclaude-can-sometimes-prove-it%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199712f9275-e0609338-0204-4d9f-9595-4fedb2997d27-000000/pVvOyrPA1jtn5z7WD058jajzSJ2Gw0xbw9QnOpI_4W4=423
summary: Claude Can (Sometimes) Prove It (19 minute read) Claude Code is quite good at interactive theorem proving (ITP), a difficult formal method used to verify critical systems. Claude Code can complete complex proof steps independently, but still requires human guidance for the overall formalization. This points towards a future where ITP is more accessible and doesn't require expert knowledge.

summary: Sj.h (GitHub Repo) Sj.h is a lightweight JSON parsing library written in C99, consisting of only about 150 lines of code. The library handles JSON structure, but requires external functions for number and string parsing.

title: Apple's Thinnest iPhone Still Stands Up to Repairs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.ifixit.com%2FNews%2F113171%2Fiphone-air-teardown%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199712f9275-e0609338-0204-4d9f-9595-4fedb2997d27-000000/PG9pjwxgtaslic8JcV9GGkHSWc3JFXKpcriKH-5STwA=423
summary: Apple's Thinnest iPhone Still Stands Up to Repairs (11 minute read) The iPhone Air, Apple's thinnest iPhone, surprisingly prioritizes repairability through clever design choices. By shifting the logic board and using a flat disassembly tree, the phone avoids stacking components, making repairs easier. The battery is easily accessible with electrically debonding adhesive, and the USB-C port is modular.

title: The Hidden Risk in Notion 3.0 AI Agents: Web Search Tool Abuse for Data Exfiltration
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.codeintegrity.ai%2Fblog%2Fnotion%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199712f9275-e0609338-0204-4d9f-9595-4fedb2997d27-000000/Wbm2Cq1272G6OygV4bNCxV2IAE9a-oDDXioP2ZXed28=423
summary: The Hidden Risk in Notion 3.0 AI Agents: Web Search Tool Abuse for Data Exfiltration (6 minute read) CodeIntegrity discovered a vulnerability in Notion 3.0's AI Agents related to its web search tool that allows for data exfiltration. By embedding a malicious prompt within a seemingly harmless PDF, attackers can trick the AI agent into querying a controlled server with sensitive data extracted from the user's Notion pages. This indirect prompt injection attack exploits the agent's tool access.

title: Monitoring Bash `readline` With eBPF CO-RE & LLM Assistance
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F@alexelbaum%2Fmonitoring-bashs-readline-with-ebpf-co-re-llm-assistance-536ab57c9b22%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/01000199718a4974-72756ea5-da09-4aa3-914f-0f13966b4222-000000/wPjN95TJHIC1Qwu4eBIVVjZqBHNWqenimonQBRz8jZc=423
summary: Monitoring Bash `readline` With eBPF CO-RE & LLM Assistance (7 minute read) Although the eBPF Compiler Collection (BCC) can monitor bash commands, it compiles programs dynamically, so the complete Clang/LLVM toolchain must be shipped to every machine. eBPF CO-RE (Compile Once - Run Everywhere) can enable portability across different kernel versions without recompilation. This article walks through how to write an eBPF program to monitor the `readline` program to monitor bash commands.

title: Flooding the AI Frontier
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fbturtel.substack.com%2Fp%2Fflooding-the-ai-frontier%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/CeZlcGAWPA4FSnoDeXbqooZpKv28S6PhbEWE5LN0KcE=423
summary: Flooding the AI Frontier (8 minute read) Chinese models are dominating the open-weight LLM space. Some of the models compete with or even outperform leading proprietary US models on common benchmarks. The Chinese government is promoting open models as part of its AI strategy. Flooding the market with free high-quality AI models helps China build its AI capabilities while making it harder for the US to sustain its lead.

title: The Extreme Inefficiency of RL for Frontier Models
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.tobyord.com%2Fwriting%2Finefficiency-of-reinforcement-learning%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/OEv-gPuYqNi4V4zQDDOnZ_Q9tj74_VKKVt70JBfgAH0=423
summary: The Extreme Inefficiency of RL for Frontier Models (15 minute read) A key difference between pre-training and reinforcement learning (RL) is their information efficiency. Pre-training via next-token-prediction provides models with a token worth of information to learn from for every token the model produces during training, while RL requires a long chain of thousands and even millions of tokens before revealing to the model a single bit of information. RL provides models with much less inform...

title: What GPT-oss Leaks About OpenAI's Training Data
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ffi-le.net%2Foss%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/ltblpYY0F6pZZDQCMns2OH_zyWEpRGPPQ89o8Z8ze3U=423
summary: What GPT-oss Leaks About OpenAI's Training Data (21 minute read) GPT-oss' weights are openly available, but the sources of training data are not clearly described in the model card. This article takes a look at the model's parameters to find out what the model was trained on. There is strong evidence that the models in the GPT-5 and GPT-oss family were trained on phrases from adult websites. There is weak evidence that part of the GPT training corpus was scraped off GitHub.

title: LLM-Deflate: Extracting LLMs Into Datasets
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-22, Reading time: 14 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.scalarlm.com%2Fblog%2Fllm-deflate-extracting-llms-into-datasets%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019971936ea2-b8d0717c-c988-467d-bd3c-df4d52df062a-000000/JTYsANyuyBtj_cHCpY6k4p3xifomA5tesERDx88b8VI=423
summary: LLM-Deflate: Extracting LLMs Into Datasets (14 minute read) Large language models compress massive amounts of training data into their parameters. This process can be reversed: structured data sets can be systematically extracted from trained models. This post discusses a decompression technique that can generate substantial training data sets from open-source models. The key is treating inference as a knowledge extraction tool rather than just a generation mechanism.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fbodadotsh%2Fnpm-security-best-practices%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/Wys4s2aqgY90KGh2Jzy0ApGHGJnTmlG7yIMHyxLklU0=423
summary: NPM Security Best Practices (13 minute read) This is a consolidated list of best practices for securing against incidents in the NPM ecosystem, covering npm, bun, deno, pnpm, and yarn. Maintainers should enable 2FA, create tokens with limited access, generate provenance statements, and always review published files.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.cloudflare.com%2Fcapnweb-javascript-rpc-library%2F%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/eF_RFW0IvL0lfbHJAmx9xOcneGExYFOLZDQ9Bgnv8JU=423
summary: Cap'n Web: a new RPC system for browsers and web servers (21 minute read) Cap'n Web is a new, open-source RPC system for JavaScript environments for facilitating communication between applications over a network. It makes setup easier, integrates with TypeScript, and uses human-readable JSON serialization.

title: Why Local-First Apps Haven't Become Popular?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmarcobambini.substack.com%2Fp%2Fwhy-local-first-apps-havent-become%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/01000199764252cf-50f04556-e1f3-4e73-9047-b5d887cb7ea0-000000/PGb_c3b_jqqfnTufBg_c41DhUf4JbY_R-Yb0gA8FTMY=423
summary: Why Local-First Apps Haven't Become Popular? (6 minute read) Local-first apps have adoption challenges due to the complexity of syncing data across devices, especially offline. The key to successful local-first apps lies in achieving eventual consistency, making sure all devices converge to the same state without data loss. This happens through techniques like Hybrid Logical Clocks (HLCs) for reliable ordering and Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) to handle data conflicts.

summary: AI-Generated “Workslop” Is Destroying Productivity (11 minute read) "Workslop" is AI-generated content that lacks substance but appears polished. This "workslop tax" has financial and interpersonal costs, bringing down trust and collaboration.

summary: The Right Size Project (7 minute read) Freelancers and small agencies should focus on "right-sized" projects rather than chasing big jobs they're not ready for. Success comes from starting with smaller projects where you can guarantee outsized results, then gradually scaling up as you build proof and confidence in delivering larger value.

title: Championing Quality Through Culture
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Ftrevorgrogers.substack.com%2Fp%2Fchampioning-quality-through-culture%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/01000199767802d3-e16b3732-e048-41af-a24f-f04e671adeb9-000000/2ktBbVWDZsMJE0URVX3ktiNEWDXovfYVb6GwaSDHqOY=424
summary: Championing Quality Through Culture (2 minute read) Quality emerges from well-designed systems and processes rather than being added at the end of projects. When systems enforce excellence and collaboration, teams can move quickly without sacrificing standards because clarity becomes built into every checkpoint. Building this culture requires long-term investment in feedback loops and accountability, making quality a natural byproduct rather than a competing priority with speed.

title: Designing loops, not paths
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-23, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fmicrosoft-design%2Fdesigning-loops-not-paths-591b7689227f%3Futm_source=tldrdesign/1/01000199767802d3-e16b3732-e048-41af-a24f-f04e671adeb9-000000/xFOHasZCzwXy2q1i4lnli567CczoqM0j_noo_ioNNjU=424
summary: Designing loops, not paths (8 minute read) Traditional workflow-based design is too rigid for real-world unpredictability, while loop-based systems use continuous feedback to sense, decide, act, and adapt. By keeping humans in the loop and enabling nested layers of oversight, these systems build resilience, foster trust, and support smarter, more flexible collaboration between people and AI.

summary: Tool Calls Are Expensive And Finite (3 minute read) Tool calling is many orders of magnitude more costly than calling a plain old function from code. summary: Tired of cookie consent pop-ups? You soon may see less of them (2 minute read) EU lawmakers are considering changes to the e-Privacy Directive that triggered the constant cookie consent pop-ups online. Ideas include browser-based consent settings or broader exceptions for essential cookies, reducing the need for repeated prompts. Industry leaders are pushing for alignment with GDPR's risk-based model, while privacy groups raise concerns that data protections could be weakened.

title: Beyond Winning: Spotify's Experiments with Learning Framework
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fengineering.atspotify.com%2F2025%2F9%2Fspotifys-experiments-with-learning-framework%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/010001997b6708c3-ffb9f835-03d2-467e-b4c8-dc8a84ceb328-000000/uUMlNe1GZeD87pGQYekmpjBZfnSfuX51fL4YnK-eRlU=424
summary: Beyond Winning: Spotify's Experiments with Learning Framework (12 minute read) Spotify's experimentation platform, Confidence, uses the Experiments with Learning (EwL) metric to measure experiment success by whether experiments yielded enough valid information to inform product decisions. Spotify's learning rate is ~64%, but its win rate is ~12%, which emphasizes that most value comes from understanding what doesn't work or detecting regressions, not just shipping improvements.

title: Thundering Herd Problem: Preventing the Stampede

summary: Thundering Herd Problem: Preventing the Stampede (8 minute read) The "thundering herd" problem occurs when a cache miss leads to a large number of concurrent requests hitting the database for the same record, overwhelming it. There are two solutions: using a distributed lock to allow only one request to access the database, or using in-process synchronization with (as an example) Java's `CompletableFuture` and `ConcurrentHashMap`. While the distributed lock works across multiple nodes, the in...

title: Why You Should Test Your Page Without JavaScript

title: Postgres' Original Project Goals: The Creators Totally Nailed It
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.crunchydata.com%2Fblog%2Fthe-postgres-project-original-goals-and-how-the-creators-totally-nailed-it%3Futm_source=tldrwebdev/1/010001997b80bcb8-311e95d6-4dea-4399-90c4-ca7a139433ef-000000/1UyUNwqSVVV3035IuJ7m4XPywxzNyuysOTX0Q0ygnR4=424
summary: Postgres' Original Project Goals: The Creators Totally Nailed It (9 minute read) PostgreSQL's original design goals from 1986 have shaped its modern success. These goals included support for complex objects, extensibility, active database features, and crash recovery, laying a flexible framework. Postgres' adherence to these principles has cemented its position as a versatile and trusted database today.

title: Context Engineering for AI Agents: Lessons from Building Manus

summary: Context Engineering for AI Agents: Lessons from Building Manus (11 minute read) Manus is an AI agent that had improved performance through context engineering techniques. The file system should be used as an extended memory, along with recitative methods to manipulate attention.

title: Sampling and structured outputs in LLMs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-09-24, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fparthsareen.com%2Fblog.html%23sampling.md%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/010001997bddc6ff-75ec5456-819c-44f5-ae0b-51615838ef13-000000/m4Ihstto1-E0YbE2J98uditlCKquZewH121DcQ41h5Y=424
summary: Sampling and structured outputs in LLMs (10 minute read) Sampling is the process of selecting a token from a model's vocabulary based on the probability distribution. Structured outputs allow models to turn unstructured data into structured data. Together, they both determine a model's next chosen token. Large language models are extremely sensitive to the slightest variation in their system prompts, templating, structured outputs, and sampling parameters.
